questions.prompt: 1. In BG 2.1, who begins to speak to Arjuna, who is overwhelmed with compassion and grief?
questions.feedback: Sanjaya describes Lord Krishna (addressed as Madhusudana) speaking to Arjuna in the midst of his grief.

questions.prompt: 2. In BG 2.2, Krishna calls Arjuna's weakness something practiced by which type of people?
questions.feedback: Krishna says this weakness is not befitting an Aryan and does not lead to higher planets or fame.

questions.prompt: 3. In BG 2.3, Krishna warns Arjuna not to give in to what (described as petty weakness of heart)?
questions.feedback: Krishna urges Arjuna to give up this weakness of heart and arise to fight.

questions.prompt: 4. In BG 2.7, Arjuna takes shelter of Krishna in what role?
questions.feedback: Arjuna admits confusion about duty and asks Krishna to instruct him as a disciple.

questions.prompt: 5. According to the purport of BG 2.7, what is the recommended way to solve life perplexities?
choices: Approach a bona fide spiritual master in disciplic succession
questions.feedback: The purport stresses approaching a bona fide spiritual master rather than remaining in confusion.

questions.prompt: 6. In BG 2.11, Krishna says the wise lament for neither the living nor the dead because they understand what?
choices: The soul is eternal and distinct from the body
questions.feedback: The wise know the soul is eternal and do not grieve as if the body were the self.

questions.prompt: 7. In BG 2.12, Krishna states that in the past, present, and future:
choices: Krishna, Arjuna, and all the kings exist as individuals
The soul merges and loses individuality
questions.feedback: Krishna says all persons exist as individuals, and will continue to exist.

questions.prompt: 8. In BG 2.13, what example is used to show that the soul continues while the body changes?
choices: Childhood to youth to old age
questions.feedback: The soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in one body; similarly it passes to another body.

questions.prompt: 9. In BG 2.14, Krishna teaches that happiness and distress arise from what?
choices: Contact of the senses with their objects
questions.feedback: He says these experiences come from sense contact and should be tolerated without disturbance.

questions.prompt: 10. In BG 2.15, a person who is steady amid happiness and distress is eligible for what?
questions.feedback: The purport explains that tolerating distress and happiness steadily makes one eligible for liberation.

questions.prompt: 11. In BG 2.16, Krishna distinguishes the real and unreal by saying:
choices: The unreal never was, and the real never ceases to be
questions.feedback: This verse establishes the permanence of the real (the soul) and the non-endurance of the unreal (temporary matter).

questions.prompt: 12. In BG 2.17, what is said to pervade the entire body?
questions.feedback: Krishna says the soul that pervades the body is indestructible and cannot be destroyed.

questions.prompt: 13. In BG 2.20, which statement best matches Krishna's description of the soul?
choices: Born with the body and dies with it
Neither born nor ever dies; eternal and primeval
questions.feedback: Krishna says the soul is unborn, eternal, ever-existing, and primeval.

questions.prompt: 14. In BG 2.22, the soul's change of bodies is compared to:
questions.feedback: As a person puts on new garments, the soul accepts new bodies and gives up old ones.

questions.prompt: 15. In BG 2.25 (purport), why must we accept the soul's existence through Vedic authority (sruti)?
choices: Because it is obvious to the eyes
Because it can be proven with microscopes
Because it is too subtle for material experiments
Because it is a social convention
questions.feedback: The purport explains the soul is too small/subtle for material proof, so we rely on Vedic wisdom.

questions.prompt: 16. In BG 2.31, Krishna says a ksatriya has no better engagement than:
questions.feedback: Krishna frames Arjuna's duty: fighting for dharma is the proper engagement for a ksatriya.

questions.prompt: 17. In BG 2.37, Krishna motivates Arjuna by saying that if he fights:
choices: He will go to heaven if killed, or enjoy the earth if victorious
questions.feedback: Krishna states the outcomes: heaven if slain, or earthly kingdom if victorious.

questions.prompt: 18. In BG 2.39 (purport), Sankhya is described as knowledge of what, and yoga as what?
choices: The real nature of the soul; control of the senses
questions.feedback: The purport defines Sankhya as describing the soul in detail, and yoga as sense control (buddhi-yoga in context).

questions.prompt: 19. In BG 2.40 (purport), why is work begun in Krishna consciousness not lost even if incomplete?
choices: Because it has a permanent spiritual effect
questions.feedback: The purport explains devotional work has lasting effect, unlike material work which can be lost if unfinished.

questions.prompt: 20. In BG 2.47 (purport), Krishna contrasts prescribed duty with which two dangers?
questions.feedback: The purport highlights three considerations: prescribed duties, capricious work, and inaction.

questions.prompt: 21. In BG 2.48 (purport), what is the key idea of acting in yoga?
choices: Act only when you feel inspired
Concentrate the mind on the Supreme and follow Krishna's direction
questions.feedback: The purport explains yoga here means focusing on the Supreme Lord; Arjuna should act by Krishna's dictation.

questions.prompt: 22. In BG 2.49 (purport), those who want to enjoy the fruits of their work are called:
questions.feedback: The purport says one who understands his position as Krishna's servant gives up fruitive desire; fruit-seekers are called misers.

questions.prompt: 23. In BG 2.55, a person is sthita-prajna when he:
choices: Gives up mental concocted sense desires and is satisfied in the self
questions.feedback: BG 2.55 defines steadiness: giving up desires arising from the mind and finding satisfaction in the self.

questions.prompt: 24. In BG 2.62-63, what sequence is described as the psychological slide that leads to downfall?
choices: Contemplation -> attachment -> desire -> anger -> delusion -> loss of memory -> loss of intelligence
questions.feedback: BG 2.62-63 outlines the chain from sense contemplation to attachment, desire, anger, delusion, and finally loss of intelligence.

questions.prompt: 25. In BG 2.70-72, which statement best captures the end-state of steady consciousness?
choices: He is flooded by desires like a small pond
Desires enter like rivers into the ocean, yet he remains undisturbed and attains peace
He must stop all activity to be peaceful
Peace comes from satisfying every desire
questions.feedback: BG 2.70 compares the steady person to an ocean that remains full though rivers enter; BG 2.72 says such godly life leads to the kingdom of God if maintained even at death.
